metadata.title: Does nano silver promote the selection of antibiotic resistance genes in soil and plant?

Does nano silver promote the selection of antibiotic resistance genes in soil and plant?
Qing-Lin Chena,b, Dong Zhua, Xin-Li Ana, Jing Dingc, Yong-Guan Zhua,c,d, Li Cuia,⁎
a Key Laboratory of Urban Environment and Health, Institute of Urban Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 1799 Jimei Road, Xiamen 361021, China b Faculty of Veterinary and Agricultural Sciences, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, Victoria 3010, Australia c State Key Laboratory of Urban and Regional Ecology, Research Center for Eco-environmental Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100085, China d College of Advanced Agricultural Sciences, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, 19A Yuquan Road, Beijing 100049, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Handling Editor: Frederic Coulon
Keywords: Nano-materials Silver nanoparticles Antibiotic resistance Co-selection Plant microbiome
A B S T R A C T
Growing evidences have demonstrated that heavy metal contamination can promote the proliferation of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) via co-selection. However, effects of nano-metal-materials on the occurrence and level of ARGs in the soil and plant, have not been fully explored. To gain insights into this impact, we conducted a pot experiment by adding nano‑silver particles (AgNPs) as a stimuli and Ag ion (AgNO3) and tetracycline as a comparison. By using high throughput quantitative PCR, our results indicated that application of AgNPs (~20 nm and ~50 nm) at a concentration of 100 ppm resulted in no significant changes in the abundance of ARGs in either soil or phyllosphere (P > 0.05). Nevertheless, the overall pattern of resistome, especially in soil, was shifted following AgNPs application, with a significance increase in the relative abundance of efflux pumps genes, which is an important mechanism for co-selection of ARGs by heavy metals. By comparison, Ag ion at an equivalent Ag mass of AgNPs markedly increased ARGs abundance and shifted ARGs profile in soil, indicating that free Ag ion had a stronger impact on ARGs than AgNPs. These findings provide new insights in assessing the risks of manufactured nanomaterials accumulated in the environment.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Discovery of antibiotics from microbial metabolic products and their introduction into clinical settings is one of the greatest advances in medical history (Wright, 2007; Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA), 2011). However, the acquisition and dissemination of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) have severely compromised the efficacy of antibiotics (Silver and Bostian, 1993; Walker et al., 2009; World Health Organization, 2014; Jiang et al., 2017). ARGs are currently regarded as emerging environmental contaminants (Pruden et al., 2006). Overuse of antibiotics in medical treatment and animal feedstuffs to promote growth was considered as the direct and primary pressure accelerating the occurrence and dissemination of ARGs in the environment (Sarmah et al., 2006; Allen et al., 2010; Marshall and Levy, 2011). In addition to antibiotics, growing evidences have suggested that metal contamination represents another widespread and recalcitrant co-selection pressure of antibiotic resistance (Baker-Austin et al., 2006; Seiler and Berendonk, 2012; Zhu et al., 2013). Arsenic (V) exposure enhanced the tolerance of bacteria to tetracycline (Chen et al., 2015; Cui et al., 2016). Moreover, field studies demonstrated that long-term copper
contamination and nickel exposure induced increases of antibiotic resistance in soils (Hu et al., 2016; Hu et al., 2017).
Nanotechnology has been advancing rapidly across a wide range of industries in the past few decades. The ability to design and massively produce nanomaterials is now leading to the extensive use of nanomaterials in different areas including medical biology, environmental pollution remediation, agricultural production and industrial catalysis (Daniel and Astruc, 2004; Selvaraj et al., 2014; Fan et al., 2017; Achari and Kowshik, 2018). However, during their production and application, a large amount of nanomaterials are being inevitably discharged and accumulated in diverse environments of water, soil and even air (Klaine et al., 2008). Presently, the toxicity of residual nanomaterials has been a topic of great interest due to the potential eco-environmental problems and risks to human health (Arora et al., 2008; Ahamed et al., 2010; George et al., 2011).
Many nanomaterials exhibit antibacterial effects (Huang et al., 2008; Lee et al., 2008; Azam et al., 2012; Panáček et al., 2018). It stands to reason that antimicrobial properties of nanomaterials could result in the potential induction of antibiotic resistance, since for some metal nanomaterials, there is some overlap with mechanisms of traditional

antibiotic action, which will offer nanomaterials select for antibiotic resistance (Aruguete et al., 2013). However, evidence regarding effects of nanomaterials on ARGs are just emerging. A prior study has suggested that nanoalumina exposure could induce oxidative stress, damage bacterial cell membranes and promote horizontal conjugative transfer of plasmid-mediated (RP4) multidrug-resistance genes across genera (Qiu et al., 2012). Further, a metagenomic analysis indicated that silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) altered the profile of ARGs, with a higher abundance of aminoglycoside resistance genes (mainly strA) in a nitrifying sequencing batch reactor (Ma et al., 2016). Among the large category of nanomaterials, AgNPs are the most extensively used nanomaterials and topped the list of engineered nanoparticles-enhanced products due to their excellent antibacterial properties (Chen and Schluesener, 2008; Sotiriou and Pratsinis, 2010). However, effect of AgNPs on the occurrence of ARGs in soil remains largely unexplored. Soil is the environmental compartment where the majority of nanomaterials will end up. It has been estimated that thousands of tons of AgNPs have been released into the soil environment every year, via atmospheric deposition, sewage sludge application, and sewage irrigation in agriculture (Keller et al., 2013; Schlich et al., 2013; McKee and Filser, 2016). Exposure to AgNPs has been demonstrated to disturb the gut bacterial community of collembolan, a typical soil animal (Zhu et al., 2018). Considering that human microbiome could be directly exposed to soil resistome or indirectly exposed via food chain, it is therefore necessary to explore the impacts of nanomaterials on soil resistome.
In this study, we systematically explored the impacts of AgNPs on both soil and plant-associated antibiotic resistome via a highthroughput qPCR (HT-qPCR) with 296 validated primer sets. The main target of this study is (1) to study the impact of AgNPs application on the profile of ARGs in soil and plant tissue; (2) to compare the impact of AgNPs, ionic Ag (AgNO3) and tetracycline on ARGs. We hypothesize that (1) AgNPs application could alter the overall patterns of resistomes; (2) AgNPs application has a stronger impact on soil resistomes and microbiome than that of plant; (3) ionic Ag and tetracycline exhibited a higher impact of resistomes.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text:
Two sizes of AgNPs (obtained from Aladdin Industrial Corporation, Hangzhou, China) at diameter of 20 nm and 50 nm were selected to test whether particle size was an important factor driving the selection of antibiotic resistance. Characteristics of the AgNPs were list as following: status, powder; purity, 99.9%; no coating; color, dark grey. AgNPs stock solution was prepared in deionized water (1000mg L−1) (Muhling et al., 2009). It has been suggested that the toxic effects of AgNPs have been reported to be from a combination of AgNPs and Ag ions released from them (Wijnhoven et al., 2009), to compare the impacts of AgNPs and Ag ions, aqueous AgNO3 (98.5–99.9% purity, highgrade) in deionized water with an equivalent Ag mass basis to that of AgNPs was tested (Roh et al., 2009). Tetracycline (CAS, 60−54−8, purity, > 98%) was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Industrial Corporation, Shanghai, China.
Soils (0–10 cm) used in the experiments were collected from a vegetable field (lettuce was just harvest and organic fertilizer was commonly used in this field) at August 2017 in Ningbo of Zhejiang Province, China (29°48′ N, 121°18′ E). Soils were air dried and passed through a 2mm mesh sieve before use. Chemical properties of soil were listed as follows: pH 6.69, total carbon 28.56 g kg−1, total nitrogen 3.34 g kg−1, Cr 42.53mg kg−1, Cu 18.70mg kg−1, Zn 57.68mg kg−1, and Pb 28.57mg kg−1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Experimental design
sections.text:
Totally eight treatments with four replicates were included in the present study (Control, AgNPs(20), AgNPs(50), Ag ion, Tet, AgNPs
(20)+Tet, AgNPs(50)+ Tet, and Ag ion + Tet). Environmental relevant concertation of Ag and tetracycline used in the present study was 100mg kg−1 and 10mg kg−1, respectively (Samarajeewa et al., 2017; Song et al., 2017). A blender was used to fully mix the soil and contaminates. Each plastic pot contained 2.5 kg soil and each treatment was performed in quadruplicate. There were 32 plastic pots in total. Seeds of Coriandrum sativum L were germinated and grown for 7 days in moist gauze, then similar size of plants were selected, and one plant was transplanted into each designated plastic pot. All plastic pots were incubated in a greenhouse with natural illumination and humidity at a temperature of 25 ± 2 °C during the day and 15 ± 2 °C in the night. Initial soil moisture content was adjusted to 70% of water-holding capacity (Fang et al., 2015), and deionized water was added to maintain the soil water content every 2 days. No fertilizers applied during the pot experiment. After 60 days, the plants were matured, and the soil and plants samples were collected and then stored at −80 °C before DNA extraction.

sections.heading: 2.2. Soil and phyllosphere DNA extraction
sections.text: Soil DNA was extracted from 0.5 g of soil using a FastDNA®Spin Kit for soil following the supplier's manual (MP Biomedical, Santa Ana, USA). Phyllosphere DNA of Coriandrum sativum L was extracted according to our previous studies (Chen et al., 2017c). Briefly, around 5 g leaf tissue was weighed into a conical flask (250mL) containing 100mL of 0.01M autoclaved phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). The flask was sonicated for 5min, and then shaken at 180 rpm at 30 °C for 1 h. The obtained solution was filtered through a nylon gauze and then a 0.22 μM cellulose membrane. The cellulose membrane was used for DNA extraction using FastDNA® Spin Kit for Soil. The quality of the DNA was assessed using an ND-1000 spectrophotometer (NanoDrop Technology, Wilmington, USA). The concentration of DNA was determined using a Qubit™ dsDNA HS Assay kit with a Qubit™ 3.0 fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., Waltham, USA). The DNA was stored at −20 °C until use.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of soil microbial communities
sections.text:
To characterize bacterial community compositions, the V4–V5 hypervariable region of 16S rRNA gene was amplified with a forward (515F) and reverse (907R) bar-coded primer (Zhou et al., 2011). For each DNA sample: 2× 50 μl PCR mixture contained 25 μl TaKaRa ExTaq, 0.5 μl BSA (20mg/L), 10 μM each primer, 5 ng DNA as template and 21.5 μl nuclease-free PCR-grade water. The PCR program was: 95 °C for 5min, followed by 25 cycles of 95 °C for 30 s, 58 °C for 30 s, 72 °C for 30 s and a final extension at 72 °C for 10min (Chen et al., 2017a). Negative controls (template DNA was replaced with water) were included for detecting any contamination during PCR preparation. The amplicons were purified, quantified, pooled and then sequenced on an Illumina Hiseq2500 platform (Novogene, Beijing).
The quality of downstream analysis was guaranteed by filtering raw pair-end reads to discard raw reads containing three or more ambiguous nucleotides, reads with a low (< 20) average quality score and short reads (< 100 nt) and barcode to generate clean joined reads spanning the complete V4-V5 region of the 16S rRNA gene (Zhang et al., 2014). The generated high-quality sequences were processed and analyzed using the QIIME pipeline (Caporaso et al., 2010). Operational taxonomic units (OTUs) were identified using the UCLUST algorithm with a phylotype defined at 97% sequence similarity (Edgar, 2010). Chimeric sequences, chloroplast and mitochondrial OTUs and singleton OTUs were discarded from the final OTU data set with filter_taxa_from_otu_table.py and filter_otus_from_otu_table.py. The database from the Ribosomal Database Project (RDP) was used for taxonomic classification (Wang et al., 2007; Cole et al., 2009). Raw sequences were deposited in the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under the accession number
PRJNA528849 (SRP189338).

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization of ARGs in soil and phyllosphere
sections.text: HT-qPCR approach was used to explore the profile of ARGs and MGEs in soil and phyllosphere. A total of 296 primer sets (Table S1) that have been validated in a previous study were used to analyze the antibiotic resistome (Zhu et al., 2013). HT-qPCR was performed using the Wafergen SmartChip Real-time PCR system. This system can be used for large scale and high throughput studies by processing 5184 reactions in nano-wells per run. Amplification was conducted in a 100 nL reaction system and all qPCR reactions were conducted in triplicate for each primer set, a non-template negative control was included. A more detailed description about the experimental procedure and data analysis can be found in previous studies (Su et al., 2015; Zhu et al., 2017). Absolute 16S rRNA gene copies were quantified with the same primer used in HT-qPCR via a Roche 480 system (Roche Molecular Systems Inc., Branchburg, USA) to determine bacterial abundance. Each 20-μl qPCR mixture consisted of 10 μl of 2× LightCycler 480 SYBR Green I Master, 0.8 μl (10mM) each primer, 2 μl (20 ng) template DNA and 6.4 μl of nuclease-free PCR-grade water. The thermal cycle was the same as that of HT-qPCR. A plasmid control containing a cloned and sequenced 16S rRNA gene fragment (4.11× 1010 copies per microliter) was used to generate eight-point calibration curves from ten-fold dilutions for standard calculation. All qPCRs were performed in technical triplicates with template-free negative control (Su et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 2.5. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Averages, standard deviations, and significance statistic were determined using R (R Core Team, 2016). Principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) based on Bray−Curtis distances was conducted using “labdsv” package to compare the profiles of resistomes and patterns of bacterial communities between treatments (Roberts, 2016). To identify bacterial communities related to ARGs compositions, we performed Mantel tests based on Spearman correlation with “vegan” package (Oksanen et al., 2017) in R and Procrustes analysis were performed using two BrayCurtis distances plots (PCoA) as input based on the matrix of microbial community and ARGs in QIIME (using the script transform_coordinate_matrices.py) (Caporaso et al., 2010). The measure of fit M2 (the sum of squared distances between matched sample pairs) and P values were determined from 10,000 permutations (Forsberg et al., 2014). Network analysis was performed to visualize the relationship between bacterial taxa and ARGs based on a significant Spearman correlation (P < 0.01). Spearman correlation was calculated in R with “psych” packages (Revelle, 2017). To reduce the frequency of false-positive results, the P values were then adjusted using Benjamini–Hochberg (BH) method (Benjamini and Hochberg, 1995). Network analysis was visualized by the interactive platform of Cytoscape (Shannon et al., 2003). Partial least squares path modelling (PLS-PM) was generated to test the casual relationships between Ag (composite variable including AgNPs and Ag ion), tetracycline, bacterial abundance, bacterial diversity and antibiotic resistome compositions in soil and phyllosphere using R package “plspm” (Sanchez et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 3.1. Composition of ARGs in soil and phyllosphere of Coriandrum sativum L
sections.text:
By using HT-qPCR, a total of 102 ARGs and 7 MGEs in soil and phyllosphere were identified (Fig. S1). In soil, the detected number of ARGs ranged from 53 to 74, much higher than that in phyllosphere ranged from 19 to 42. These ARGs conferred resistance to almost all major classes of antibiotics commonly administered to human and animals, including aminoglycoside, beta-lactams, chloramphenicol,
macrolide-lincosamide-streptogramin B (MLSB), multidrug, sulfonamide, tetracycline and vancomycin. Shared ARGs between soil and phyllosphere were analyzed using bipartite association network (Fig. S2). The representative ARGs subtypes that occurred in at least 60% of total soil and phyllosphere samples were selected to generate the network. We found that 14 genes including ten ARGs and 4 MGEs were shared between soil and phyllosphere and these genes mainly conferred resistance to aminoglycoside, tetracycline and multidrug.
The absolute abundance of ARGs in soil and phyllosphere were ranged from 2.30×108 to 3.23×109 copies/g soil, and 8.55×105 to 1.58×107 copies/g leaf tissue (Fig. 1). The difference of ARGs abundance between soil and phyllosphere was mainly related to their background bacterial abundances. We found that the abundance of 16S rRNA gene in soil was ~5.06×1010 copies/g soil, more than two orders of magnitude higher than that in phyllosphere (~2.79×108 copies/g leaf tissue). In addition to the abundance of ARGs, the principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) based on Bray−Curtis distances showed that the profile of ARGs in phyllosphere was distinct from that of soil (Adonis P < 0.001) (Fig. 2A).
3.2. Effect of AgNPs on the profiles of ARGs
Application of either ~20 nm or ~50 nm AgNPs was not found to induce any significant increases in the total abundance of ARGs in either soil or phyllosphere (ANOVA, LSD, P > 0.05) (Fig. 1). In contrast to AgNPs, Ag ion and tetracycline resulted in significant increases in the abundance of ARGs (ANOVA, LSD, P < 0.05), and the joint treatment of Ag ion and tetracycline (Ag ion+Tet) induced the most abundant ARGs. While the joint effect of AgNPs and tetracycline caused no markedly increase in the abundance of ARGs (ANOVA, LSD, P > 0.05). Antibiotic deactivation, efflux pumps and cellular protection were the major resistance mechanisms (Fig. 3). The percentage of efflux pumps was 26.4% in control, and significantly increased after application of Ag ion and tetracycline (P < 0.01). The maximum percentage of efflux
pumps was 71.4% in the treatment of AgNPs(50)+ Tet. In contrast, the percentage of cellular protection was decreased after the application of AgNPs, Ag ion and tetracycline.
In the case of the profile of resistomes, the Adonis test indicated that the treatment groups differed from the control in both phyllosphere (P=0.021) and soil (P < 0.001). Principal coordinates analysis also shows that samples from the treatment group were separated from the
control along with the first two axis, which explained 36.33% and 49.86% of the total variance in phyllosphere and soil, respectively (Fig. 4, Fig. S3).

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of AgNPs on the assembly of bacterial communities
sections.text:
After assembling and quality filtering, a total of 5,497,077 high
quality sequences were obtained from soil and phyllosphere samples, with sequences per sample ranging from 20,918 to 94,152. These sequences were clustered into 88,901 OTUs at the 97% similarity level, with an average of 21,057 and 1932 OTUs per sample being identified in soil and phyllosphere, respectively. The profile of bacterial community in soil differed significantly from phyllosphere (Adonis, P < 0.001) (Fig. 2B), which was also confirmed by the taxonomic composition even at the phylum level (Fig. S4).
Principal coordinates analysis showed that the application of AgNPs, Ag ion and tetracycline altered bacterial community compositions in both soil (Fig. 4) and phyllosphere (Fig. S3), which was also supported by the Adonis test. Compared with AgNPs, Ag ion application caused a larger shift in the profile of bacterial communities in the soil, as revealed by the treatment of Ag ion was separated from the control mainly along PC1 (explained 64.45% of variance), whereas AgNPs was separated from the control along PC2 (explained 9.52% of variance) (Fig. 4).

sections.heading: 3.4. Correlation between bacterial phylogeny structures and antibiotic resistome
sections.text: We explored the correlation between antibiotic resistome and bacterial community compositions to test whether AgNPs, AgNO3 and tetracycline altered the antibiotic resistome by shaping the phylogeny structures of bacterial communities. The results showed that the BrayCurtis distances calculated from ARG compositions (HT-qPCR data) were significantly correlated with bacterial OTUs inferred from 16S rRNA sequence data (Mantel tests, r=0.68, P < 0.001). Procrustes analyses (Fig. 5) revealed that both the ARGs profiles of soil and phyllosphere correlated with bacterial composition (M2= 0.45, P < 0.001, 10,000 permutations). Network analysis of co-occurrence pattern between ARGs and bacterial taxa also suggested a significant relationship between subtype of ARG and bacterial taxa, with that 29 bacterial taxa identified having a significant (P < 0.01) correlation with ARG subtypes (Fig. S5).

sections.heading: 4.1. Effect of AgNPs and AgNO3 on the abundance of ARGs
sections.text:
Our study indicated that the application of two sizes (~20 nm and ~50 nm) of AgNPs at a concentration of 100mg kg−1, resulted in no significant change in the abundance of ARGs in either soil or phyllosphere. But Ag ion significantly increased the abundance of ARG, especially in soil. Considering the concentrations used for AgNPs and Ag ion were in an equivalent Ag mass, our results suggested that free silver ion exerted a larger selection pressure on ARGs than AgNPs. AgNPs of a smaller size normally had a larger specific surface area and thus generated more free ions than larger size. However, the larger specific surface area of AgNPs, the more easily adsorbed and aggregated in soil, leading to decrease of bioavailability. This might explain that the size of AgNPs did not exert significantly different effects on the abundance of ARGs.
We also observed that either single application of tetracycline or joint application of tetracycline and AgNO3 resulted in significant increases in the abundance of ARG, and a higher abundance was observed in the joint application. However, the joint application of tetracycline and AgNPs caused no significant changes in the abundance of ARG. It is hypothesized that the toxic effects of AgNPs are due to a combination of the specific properties of AgNPs and free ions generated from them (Wijnhoven et al., 2009). Here we defined this combination as ‘nanoparticle-ion duality’, which included ‘nanoparticle effect’ and ‘ion effect’. The nanoparticle effect and ion effect may be different on the selection of ARGs. Based on the present results, we inferred that the ‘nanoparticle effect’ may induce decrease in the ARG abundance, while the ‘ion effect’ like AgNO3 may exert a selection pressure on ARGs. The contribution of ‘nanoparticle effect’ and ‘ion effect’ on selection of ARGs could vary and depend on the surrounding environments. Such variations were illustrated by two recent studies. In one study, they observed an elevation of the abundance of strA and acrB associated with AgNPs dosed in lab-scale nitrifying sequencing batch reactors (Ma et al., 2016). In another one, Zhu et al., found that AgNPs exposure lowered the incidence of ARGs in the collembolan gut microbiota (Zhu et al., 2018). Therefore, more studies are needed to explore what factors and how they affect the balance of ‘nanoparticle effect’ and ‘ion effect’ of
AgNPs. In contrast to soil, the abundance of ARGs in phyllosphere showed no significant changes (P > 0.05) in all of the treatments. Although it has been demonstrated that plant could uptake antibiotic from soil organic fertilizer (Kumar et al., 2005), application of tetracycline resulted in no changes in the abundance of resistomes. The different results between soil and phyllosphere could be due to that the leaf-associated microorganisms are exposed to multiple stress factors including the elevated and fluctuating salinity, periodic desiccation, high temperatures, and UV radiation (Finkel et al., 2012; Finkel et al., 2016). Many of these factors could affect the community composition of phyllosphere bacteria and weaken the possible impacts of AgNPs and AgNO3. Altogether, our results indicated that soil exposure to AgNPs, AgNO3 and tetracycline at the present concentration had minor impact on the abundance of the leaf-associated resistomes.
4.2. Effect of AgNPs and AgNO3 on the profiles of ARGs and bacterial communities
Despite AgNPs induced no significant changes in the abundance of ARGs, PCoA analysis indicated a significant shift on the overall pattern of ARGs following AgNPs application in soil. More specifically, we found that the relative abundance of efflux pumps genes increased after AgNPs, Ag ion and tetracycline application. Efflux pump is an important mechanism of antibiotic resistance in gram-negative bacteria (Allen et al., 2010). These pumps could expel antibiotics from the cell. Moreover, some pumps could expel both antibiotics and metals from the cell and thus play an important role in the co-selection of ARGs. For example, tetL protein can transport both tetracycline and cobalt (Co) out of cells (Baker-Austin et al., 2006). At nano scale, the properties and toxicity of AgNPs may be distinct from that of their parent materials, however, our results suggested that AgNPs still potentially co-select for antibiotic resistance via efflux pumps.
A significant relationship between bacterial communities and ARGs profiles was revealed via mantel test and Procrustes analysis in this study, consistent with the strong correlations found in other environments including soils (Chen et al., 2016), plants (Chen et al., 2017c), sewage sludge (Su et al., 2015), drinking water (Jia et al., 2015) and groundwater (Chen et al., 2017b). Furthermore, partial least squares path modelling indicated a significant positive correlation between bacterial abundance and ARGs, but a weak negative relationship between bacterial diversity and ARGs (Fig. S6). Similar result was also
observed in previous study using structural equation model (Chen et al., 2018). In addition, both Ag (including AgNPs and AgNO3) and tetracycline can indirectly affect ARGs by shifting the bacterial abundance and diversity (Fig. S6). It is not surprisingly to observe a negative correlation between Ag and bacterial abundance and diversity, since Ag (AgNPs or Ag ion) are well known for their excellent antimicrobial activity on bacteria (Xiu et al., 2012; Soenen et al., 2015). However, it was interesting to find a positive relationship between tetracycline and the bacterial abundance and diversity. This could be related to the “rhizosphere effect”, because we observed that tetracycline application promoted plant and root growth (data not shown), and exudation of nutrient from root may promote the bacterial proliferation.
Altogether, the present study provided the experimental evidence about the impact of AgNPs on the profile of ARGs in soil and associated plants. Our results indicated that AgNPs application caused no significant increase in the total abundance of ARGs, different from AgNO3 that significantly elevated the soil ARGs level. Nevertheless, AgNPs application altered the overall pattern of bacterial communities, which significantly correlate with the profile resistome. The significant increase in the relative abundance of efflux pumps genes, suggesting that AgNPs may facilitate the spread of antibiotic resistance by co-selection. These results extend our knowledge regarding the effects of AgNPs on the ecosystem and may help us understand the role of AgNPs in the coselection of ARGs in the soil and plant associated microbiome.

metadata.abstractText: Growing evidences have demonstrated that heavy metal contamination can promote the proliferation of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) via co-selection. However, effects of nano-metal-materials on the occurrence and level of ARGs in the soil and plant, have not been fully explored. To gain insights into this impact, we conducted a pot experiment by adding nano‐silver particles (AgNPs) as a stimuli and Ag ion (AgNO3) and tetracycline as a comparison. By using high throughput quantitative PCR, our results indicated that application of AgNPs (~20 nm and ~50 nm) at a concentration of 100 ppm resulted in no significant changes in the abundance of ARGs in either soil or phyllosphere (P > 0.05). Nevertheless, the overall pattern of resistome, especially in soil, was shifted following AgNPs application, with a significance increase in the relative abundance of efflux pumps genes, which is an important mechanism for co-selection of ARGs by heavy metals. By comparison, Ag ion at an equivalent Ag mass of AgNPs markedly increased ARGs abundance and shifted ARGs profile in soil, indicating that free Ag ion had a stronger impact on ARGs than AgNPs. These findings provide new insights in assessing the risks of manufactured nanomaterials accumulated in the environment.
